title: Cedar Island National Wildlife Refuge
text:
Cedar Island National Wildlife Refuge, located in <a href="Carteret%20County%2C%20North%20Carolina">Carteret County, North Carolina</a>, is on the end of a <a href="peninsula">peninsula</a> marking the southern end of <a href="Pamlico%20Sound">Pamlico Sound</a>. The refuge lies five miles (8 km) east of the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> and about northeast of <a href="Beaufort%2C%20North%20Carolina">Beaufort, North Carolina</a>. Established in 1964, the refuge consists of approximately of irregularly flooded, <a href="brackish%20marsh">brackish marsh</a> and of <a href="pocosin">pocosin</a> and <a href="woodland">woodland</a> habitat. The dominant marsh plants include <a href="Juncus%20roemerianus">black needlerush</a>, <a href="Spartina%20alterniflora">saltmarsh cordgrass</a>, <a href="Spartina%20patens">saltmeadow hay</a>, and <a href="saltgrass">saltgrass</a>. The woodland areas are dominated by <a href="loblolly%20pine">loblolly</a>, <a href="longleaf%20pine">longleaf</a> and <a href="pond%20pine">pond pine</a>. <a href="Live%20oak">Live oak</a> is also abundant on some upland sites. The marsh and surrounding waters provide wintering habitat for thousands of <a href="duck">duck</a>s and nesting habitat for colonial waterbirds.
Mammalian species that inhabit this refuge are <a href="gray%20squirrel">gray squirrel</a>, <a href="marsh%20rabbit">marsh rabbit</a>, <a href="white-tailed%20deer">white-tailed deer</a>, <a href="red%20fox">red fox</a>, <a href="raccoon">raccoon</a>, <a href="bobcat">bobcat</a>, <a href="gray%20fox">gray fox</a>, <a href="nutria">nutria</a>, <a href="North%20American%20beaver">beaver</a>, <a href="muskrat">muskrat</a>, <a href="North%20American%20river%20otter">river otter</a>, <a href="American%20mink">mink</a> and <a href="Virginia%20opossum">opossum</a>.
